In oceanography, what is the term for the deepest part of the ocean, reaching depths of over 36,000 feet?
A. Abyssal Plain
B. Continental Shelf
C. Mid-Ocean Ridge
D. Mariana Trench

The term for the deepest part of the ocean, reaching depths of over 36,000 feet, is the Mariana Trench. So, the correct answer is D. Mariana Trench.

To provide some more information, the Mariana Trench is located in the western Pacific Ocean, east of the Mariana Islands. It is home to the Challenger Deep, which is the deepest known point in the Earth's seabed hydrosphere, with a depth of approximately 35,814 feet (10,916 meters). This extreme depth makes it a challenging environment for marine life and exploration.

The other options are also important features of the ocean but do not refer to the deepest part:

A. Abyssal Plain: These are large, relatively flat areas of the ocean floor, typically found at depths of around 13,000 to 16,000 feet (4,000 to 5,000 meters). They cover more than 50% of the ocean floor and are important for seafloor spreading and sedimentation.

B. Continental Shelf: This is the extended perimeter of each continent and which is covered during interglacial periods such as the current epoch by relatively shallow sea and gulfs.

C. Mid-Ocean Ridge: This is a continuous mountain range located along the crest of the oceanic ridge system. It is formed by plate tectonics and is the site of seafloor spreading.

So, while all these features are important in oceanography, the Mariana Trench is specifically known for being the deepest part of the ocean.
